title: Rush - analogkid Single 320 1982 ak6103
description:
Signals is the ninth studio album by Canadian rock band Rush, released in 1982. Stylistically, the album was a continuation of Rush's foray into the technology-oriented 1980s through increased use of electronic , sequencers Other noticeable changes were decreased song length and lyrical compression. The album reached #10 on the Billboard charts and was certified platinum by the RIAA in November 1982
In January 1982, in the Virgin Islands, Peart presented his lyrics for "The Analog Kid" to Lee and they both agreed that it would make a great up-tempo rocker. At Muskoka Lakes, Ontario in March at the Grange, "Digital Man" was put together and at Le Studio, along with the sequencer pattern with the guitar and bass. Producer Terry Brown was not impressed and initially refused to record it
.

Neil Peart Ã¢â‚¬â€œ Tama drums, Avedis Zildjian cymbals, Wuhan China Type Cymbals, percussion

"The Analog Kid" and "Digital Man" served as the inspiration for writer Troy Hickman to create the comic book heroes of the same names in the 2004 comic Common Grounds.

It is the last time to date that Lee or Lifeson have contributed lyrics to a Rush song.
image
"Digital Man", a slightly reggae-based song, ultimately led to the end of the band's relationship with Brown. He was reluctant to leave behind the band's progressive-rock past, they wanted to explore new musical directions. . A slightly adapted version of the song was brought back for the 2007 Snakes And Arrows Tour, marking the first time Rush performed it in nearly 23 years.
image
"The Analog Kid"

Released: 1983
Written by Geddy Lee, Alex Lifeson and Neil Peart
